The Verse Compendium of the Perfection of Wisdom
In Sanskrit: Ārya-prajñāpāramitā-ratnaguṇa-sañcaya-gāthā
In Tibetan: The Noble Compendium in verse of the Perfection of wisdom

Homage to Noble Mañjuśrī.
Then the Blessed One, in order to thoroughly delight the four cycles of monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, again taught this Perfection of wisdom. At that time, he proclaimed these verses:

With supreme joy, reverence, and faith firmly established,
Having dispelled obscurations and afflictions, transcending all defilements,
Hear now the Perfection of Wisdom of those gentle bodhisattvas
Who have authentically entered into accomplishing the welfare of beings—
Listen to these profound practices wherein the courageous ones engage.
# The First Chapter on the Knowledge of All Aspects

All the rivers flowing throughout this Jambudvīpa,
Nurturing flowers, fruits, medicines, and forests that flourish—
They depend upon the lord of nāgas, the master of nāgas abiding in Anavatapta,
This entire abundance manifests through the power and glory of that sovereign of nāgas.
Whatever teachings the Śrāvakas of the Victorious One impart,
Whatever explanations they offer with reasoning and analysis,
Whatever supreme transcendent happiness they cultivate and fruits they attain—
All these arise solely through the power of the Tathāgata.
Why is it that when the Victorious One teaches the path of Dharma—
Those noble disciples who have thoroughly trained in the doctrine of selflessness,
Having directly realized it, teach precisely as they have trained through progressive stages?
It is through the Buddha's power they accomplish this, not through their own power.
When neither the supreme Perfection of Wisdom is not apprehended,
Nor is a bodhisattva not apprehended, nor bodhicitta not apprehended,
One who, upon hearing this, remains neither confused nor afraid—
That bodhisattva truly practices the wisdom of the Sugata.
Neither form nor feeling, neither perception nor volition exists;
Not even the slightest particle of consciousness remains as a foundation.
Practicing without abiding in any phenomena, abiding nowhere,
Free from all grasping, one attains the awakening of the Sugatas.
Just as Shrenika the ascetic, through discriminating wisdom,
Realizes the aggregates as without reference points and thus causes them to perish,
So too, any bodhisattva who comprehends phenomena in this way,
Abides in wisdom, not touching nirvana.
Again, the bodhisattva investigates: "What is this wisdom?
To whom does it belong? From where does it arise?"
Contemplating how all phenomena are empty of inherent existence,
Finding that wisdom itself arises from no ultimate source,
The bodhisattva remains neither disheartened by emptiness
Nor frightened by this profound analysis,
Balanced in understanding both ultimate and conventional truths—
Such a bodhisattva is drawing near to awakening.
If one perceives form without true understanding,
And engages with feeling, volition, and consciousness as inherently real aggregates,
Even while conceptualizing "these aggregates are empty," such a bodhisattva
Is still operating within the realm of conceptual signs, without faith in the unborn state.
One who dwells not in form, nor feeling, nor perception, nor volition,
Who engages not with consciousness, but practices without abiding anywhere,
Such a one does not apprehend "practice"—relying instead on wisdom,
Endowed with the realization of the unborn, touches the supreme peace of meditative absorption.
The bodhicitta, abiding here in self-peace, 
Has been prophesied by the Tathāgatas of old.
Neither thinking "I am in meditative equipoise" nor "I have arisen from it"—conceit—
Why? Because they have thoroughly comprehended the intrinsic nature of all phenomena.
Practicing thus, one practices the wisdom of the Sugatas,
Yet thoroughly understands that true practice is non-practice.
Whatever phenomena one might practice becomes no reference point—
This is the supreme practice of the Perfection of Wisdom.
That which does not truly exist is called "non-existent,"  
Yet ordinary beings examine it, fabricating existence and non-existence.  
Both existence and non-existence are themselves qualities of phenomena—  
The bodhisattva who understands this will surely find liberation.
One who understands the five aggregates as illusion-like,
Who makes no distinction between the illusion and the aggregates themselves,
Who is free from diverse conceptualizations and dwells in perfect peace—
This is the supreme practice of the Perfection of Wisdom.
One endowed with virtuous spiritual friends and penetrating insight  
Will never be frightened upon hearing the Mother of all Victorious Ones.  
But one who keeps harmful companions and depends on others  
Is like an unfired clay vessel that shatters at water's touch.
Why is one called a bodhisattva?
One who cuts through attachment while seeking the complete elimination of all forms of attachment,
Who will touch the awakening of the Victorious Ones—that free from attachment true nature,
Therefore, this one attains the name "bodhisattva.\
Why are they called "Great Beings"?  
Because they have risen supreme among countless sentient beings,  
And because they sever the vast entrenched views that bind the realms of sentient beings—  
For these reasons, they are proclaimed to be "Great Beings.\
With great giving, vast wisdom, and powerful might,  
Having entered the supreme Mahāyāna path of the Victorious Ones,  
Wearing the armor of resolve and vanquishing Māra's deceptions—  
For these reasons, they are rightfully proclaimed a "Great mind.\
Just as a magician at a crossroads creates emanations,
Seemingly slicing off countless heads of a great crowd;
So too the bodhicitta realizes all beings—
Like those illusory victims—are mere emanations, and thus thoroughly understands no fear.
Form, perception, feeling, volition, and consciousness—  
Neither bound nor free, they have no inherent existence.  
Thus engaging in the path to awakening with unwavering mind,  
This is the supreme armor worn by supreme beings.
Why is this called the Great Vehicle of awakening?  
Because by mounting it, one guides all sentient beings beyond sorrow.  
This vehicle is like space itself—a vast, immeasurable mansion,  
The supreme vehicle that manifestly brings joy, happiness, and attain-ment.
One cannot observe any practitioner mounting the vehicle and journeying toward spiritual levels;
What is conventionally said to "go to nirvana" has no not apprehended going in ultimate truth.
Just as when a person dies, they have no cause to which they travel,
For this cause precisely, it is declared to have "passed beyond sorrow.\
The bodhisattva perceives neither past nor future,  
Nor are the present times apprehended—thus purity of the three times.  
Such is unconditioned, free from conceptual elaboration—  
This is the practice of the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
When the wise and knowing bodhisattva, at that stage of attainment,
Practices while contemplating the unborn in this way,
Generates great compassion yet without perception of sentient beings—
This is the supreme practice of the Perfection of Wisdom.
If one perceives sentient beings as real and suffering as substantial,
Thinking, "I shall benefit sentient beings" and "I shall remove their suffering,"
Such a bodhisattva, mental fabrication of self and sentient beings as inherently real,
Is not practicing the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
As you understand your self, so understand all sentient beings;
As you understand all sentient beings, so understand all phenomena.
Neither conceptualizing non-arising nor arising—both extremes transcended—
This is the practice of the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
Among all phenomena names proclaimed throughout the world,
Having abandoned both the extreme of arising and the extreme of completely transcended for all phenomena,
One attains the supreme, deathless primordial wisdom—beyond which there is nothing else—
Therefore, this is called the Perfection of Wisdom.
Thus practicing without doubt, the bodhisattva
Should be known as one who possesses wisdom and abides in the equality of all phenomena.
Thoroughly comprehending that all phenomena lack intrinsic nature by their very essence—
This is the practice of the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.

The Second Section: Teaching the Wisdom of All Paths
One who does not abide in form, nor abide in feeling,
One who does not abide in perception, nor abide in volition,
One who does not abide in consciousness—such a one abides in the nature of reality.
This is the practice of the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
Neither in permanence nor impermanence, neither in happiness nor in suffering, neither in attraction nor repulsion,
Neither in self nor in selflessness, neither in suchness nor in the empty of suchness,
Neither in the attainment of fruit nor on the earth of Arhats does one abide,
Nor on the earth of Pratyekabuddhas, nor likewise on the earth of Buddhahood.
Just as the Guide abides neither in the unconditioned element,
Nor dwells within the conditioned phenomena, but practices without abode,
So too the bodhisattva abides in all objects without abode—
This paradoxical without abode abiding is what the Victorious One has taught as true abiding.
Those who think, "May I become a Śrāvaka of the Sugata,"  
And those who wish to be Solitary Buddhas or likewise Dharma King—  
Without relying on this patience, they cannot attain their goal,  
Just as one cannot cross from this shore to the far shore without seeing the way.
The teacher of Dharma, the one who hears, and all that is taught,  
The fruit of attainment, the Solitary Realizers, and the World Protectors,  
Whatever nirvana is attained by the wise ones with luminous understanding—  
All these, the Tathāgata has shown to be like an illusion.
These four persons do not tremble when facing profound teachings:
The Bodhisattva who is wise in truth, and the irreversible one;
The Arhat who has purified all defilements and abandoned doubt;
And fourth, one who is completely embraced by a virtuous spiritual friend.
Thus practicing, the wise and knowing bodhisattva  
Neither trains for the Arhat's earth nor for the Pratyekabuddha's earth.  
For the sake of omniscience, they follow the Buddha qualities—  
Not training in what is or isn't training: this is true training.
One does not train to increase, diminish, or possess forms,
Nor does one train to acquire various phenomena.
While training, one embraces omniscience without grasping—
This is the path of definite emergence for those who have joy in qualities.
Form is not wisdom, nor is wisdom found within form.
Consciousness, perception, feeling, and volition—
These are not wisdom, nor is wisdom found within them.
Like the space element itself, undifferentiated and boundless.
The limitless intrinsic nature of all reference points extends beyond all bounds;
The intrinsic nature of sentient beings likewise has no end.
The intrinsic nature of the space element is equally boundless;
The wisdom of the Buddhas, who truly know the world, is likewise without limit.
"Perception," proclaimed the Guide, "binds one to this shore of existence;
Those who thoroughly dismantle perception through discriminating wisdom cross to the far shore.
Those who have attained freedom from all perception of inherent existence
Have reached the far shore and abide in the Teacher's ultimate teaching.\
Even if the Teacher remained for kalpas as numerous as the grains of sand in the Ganges,
Continuously proclaiming the term "sentient beings" throughout that time,
Since beings are primordially pure, how could they possibly ever have arising?
This is the practice of the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
"Thus speaks the Victorious One: 'When I attained profound realization of this supreme perfection,
At that moment, Buddha Dīpaṃkara, the supreme being of ancient times,
Prophesied about me, saying: "You, brahmin Megha, shall become a Buddha in a future age."
Having achieved the patience regarding non-arising phenomena, I received this irreversible prophecy of my enlightenment.'\


Whoever with reverence holds and fully comprehends
This Perfection of Wisdom wherein the protectors practice,
Will not be harmed by poison, weapons, fire, or water,
Nor will Māra and his forces find opportunity to obstruct their path.
Some might build stupas for the Sugata who has passed beyond sorrow,
Crafted from the seven precious substances, and make offerings to them.
Imagine these stupas of the Sugata, as countless as the sands of the Ganges,
Filling thousands of millions of buddha-fields throughout the cosmos.
If in countless billions of buddha-fields, all sentient beings dwelling therein
Were to offer worship with divine flowers, finest incense, and fragrant ointments,
Engaging in no other karma, making offerings three times
For an entire kalpa or even longer than that.
Whoever inscribes in a book this Mother of the Sugatas—
The source from which the ten powers of the Guides arise—
And carries it, honoring it with flowers and fragrant ointments,
Earns merit to which building and offering to supports cannot compare even fractionally.
This Perfection of Wisdom of the Victorious Ones is a great vidyāmantra,
Which pacifies sorrow, suffering, and all phenomena for myriad realms of sentient beings.
All the World Protectors—those who have passed away and those who abide in the ten directions—
Have trained in this vidyāmantra and become unsurpassed Kings of Healers who cure the very root of suffering.
Those who practice the bodhisattva practice infused with benefit and compassion,
Training in this vidyāmantra and becoming wise, will attain awakening.
Whether it be the happiness of conditioned phenomena or the unconditioned happiness—
All these forms of happiness should be understood to arise from this Perfection of Wisdom,
Which liberates one from conceptualizing actor, karma, and object.
Just as seeds, when sown, abide within the earth before emerging,
And flourish into myriad forms once meeting proper conditions;
So too the five perfections and all qualities of awakening,
All these arise and flourish from the Perfection of Wisdom.
Wherever the universal monarch journeys,
Along that very path follow the seven precious substances and all his forces.
Wherever this Perfection of Wisdom of the Victorious Ones proceeds,
From there all qualities and phenomena naturally flow.


When the Victorious One thoroughly questioned Indra, he gave this response:
"Even if there were Buddha-fields as numerous as the sands of the Ganges,
And all were filled to the brim with the Victorious Ones' sacred relics,
I myself would choose this very Perfection of Wisdom.\
Why is this so? It is not that I lack reverence for the Buddha's physical remains.  
Rather, I offer homage through the thorough cultivation of wisdom.  
Just as those in service to a king receive honor by association,  
So do the Buddha's relics depend on the Perfection of Wisdom.
A precious jewel with all qualities, beyond all price,
Makes worthy of veneration whatever container holds it.
Even when the jewel is removed, people still cherish its vessel—
These qualities truly belong to the precious jewel itself.
Similarly, through the supreme qualities of the Perfection of Wisdom,
Even though the Victorious One has passed into nirvana, his relics receive offerings.
Therefore, whoever wishes to uphold the qualities of the Victorious Ones'
Should take up the Perfection of Wisdom—this is liberation.
Wisdom, realizing emptiness, precedes the act of generosity,
As with ethical discipline, patience, diligent effort, and meditative absorption;
It embraces all virtuous qualities, freeing them from the three spheres of conception,
Preventing waste in lesser attainments, transforming them to perfections of one taste—
Like diverse trees casting shadows of a single nature—all leading to supreme enlightenment.
Just as in Jambudvīpa countless millions of trees stand—
Diverse in kind, manifold in type, and varied in form—
Yet their shadows show no such variety or distinction;
They are merely counted as shadows, nothing more.
In like manner, these five perfections of the Victorious Ones  
Acquire the very name of the Perfection of Wisdom.  
When dedicated toward omniscience,  
All six, known as "awakening," become of one taste.


When a bodhisattva, without true understanding,
Teaches form, perception, feeling, volition, and consciousness
As merely impermanence, they practice an artificial teaching.
The wise one never perish the phenomena.
Wherein no form exists, no feeling arises, no perception is not apprehended,  
Where consciousness is not found, and volition is not apprehended,  
Where one thoroughly understands all phenomena as unborn and empty—  
This is the supreme practice of the Perfection of Wisdom.
If someone were to guide all sentient beings to Arhat—
As many sentient beings as dwell in buddha-fields as numerous as the sands of the Ganges—
The merit of one who writes down this Perfection of Wisdom
And presents the text to noble sentient beings vastly surpasses that deed.
Why is this so? Because these supreme speakers, having trained these teachings,
Reveal here that all phenomena are completely emptiness.
Hearing this, Śrāvakas swiftly attain liberation,
While others reach Pratyekabuddha awakening or the buddha enlightenment.
Just as in this world, without a sprout no tree can ever grow,
And thus no branches, leaves, nor flowers and fruit could ever show;

So without bodhicitta, no Awakened Ones arise within the world,
And how then could the fruits of Indra, Brahma, or the Śrāvakas be unfurled?
When the solar disk radiates its network of light throughout the ten directions,
Sentient beings naturally engage in their various activities with diligence;
Likewise, when bodhicitta arises in the world among those wise ones seeking perfect awakening,
Through this primordial wisdom, sentient beings become endowed with qualities and phenomena.
Just as without the nāga selflessness in Lake Anavatapta,
How could rivers ever flow throughout this Jambudvīpa?
Without rivers, neither flowers nor fruits would emerge,
And the oceans would be bereft of their manifold precious jewels.
Without bodhicitta here, how could the Sugata's primordial wisdom
Possibly stream forth throughout all these worlds?
Without primordial wisdom, there is no growth of qualities, no awakening,
Nor would the ocean-like Buddha qualities continue to exist.
In this world, however many light-emitting living beings exist,
All of which radiate their brilliance to illuminate their surroundings,
A single ray from the solar disk is supremely superior—
The combined light of all luminous hosts cannot match even a fraction of it.


However vast the merit that Śrāvakas may produce  
Through generosity, ethical discipline, and meditation,  
A single moment of a bodhisattva's rejoicing mind  
Outshines the entire merit aggregates of all Śrāvakas combined.
Those countless billions of Buddhas from ages past,
And those who currently dwell in infinite thousands of empty buddha-fields,
As well as those World Protectors who have entered nirvana yet whose teachings remain—
All teach the precious jewel of Dharma to completely eliminate all suffering.
From the moment supreme enlightenment first awakens in the mind,
Until the sacred Dharma of all the Guides vanishes from the world,
Whatever merit those Victorious Ones accumulate during this time—
Along with their perfections and all the Buddha qualities—
The bodhisattva gathers all the merit of Buddha's spiritual heirs and Śrāvakas,
Those in training and those beyond training, their virtue pure and those with traces;
With heartfelt rejoicing, the bodhisattva then rejoices in this goodness,
And dedicates it all to perfect awakening for sentient beings' purpose.
If, while dedicating merit, you perceive a truly existing mind,
And cling to notions of awakening, dedication, and sentient beings,
Then due to these perceptions, your view remains fixed, your mind attached to these three spheres.
Such dedication—bound by reference points—cannot be considered genuine.
If one understands that these phenomena have ceased and are exhausted,
And that to which merit is dedicated is likewise without substance,
And if one realizes that phenomena never truly dedicate to phenomena,
Then through such profound wisdom, perfect dedication is accomplished.
If one makes dedication with conceptual signs, that is not true dedication;
When free from signlessness, it becomes dedication toward awakening.
Just as consuming excellent food mixed with poison brings harm,
So too the Victorious One taught of focusing on virtuous phenomena with a reference point.
Therefore, one should train in the art of dedication as follows:  
Just as the Victorious Ones perceive the nature of virtue  
In all its aspects, origins, and defining characteristics,  
So I rejoice and dedicate in precisely that same way.
When thus completely dedicating merit to awakening,
One speaks the Buddha's teaching free from poison, never straying from the path.
The hero who dedicates merit in this non-referential way
Outshines all worldly bodhisattvas, however many there may be.


Even millions of blind ones without guides—
How could they, not knowing the path, ever enter the city?
So too these five perfections without wisdom are eyeless;
Without a guide, they cannot reach awakening.
When thoroughly embraced by wisdom,
The perfections gain their sight and attain their name.
Like a finished painting lacking eyes—
No payment comes until the eyes are drawn.
When wisdom thoroughly dismantles all phenomena—
Conditioned phenomena and unconditioned, white and black phenomena—
And not apprehended even the slightest particle,
Then in the world, this is counted as the Perfection of Wisdom,
Like space, which does not abide in nothing whatsoever.
If I think, "I will practice the wisdom of the Victorious Ones
And liberate countless millions of sentient beings touched by suffering,"
Yet maintain the perception and mental fabrication of "sentient beings,"
Then I am not practicing the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
When a bodhisattva who in former times
Skillfully practiced these perfections without doubt,
Merely upon hearing them again, generates the perception of the Teacher—
Such a one will swiftly realize the peaceful awakening.
Though one may have honored and served countless Buddhas in former lives,
If one lacks faith in the Victorious Ones' Perfection of Wisdom,
Then upon hearing it, with limited wisdom, one will reject these teachings;
Having rejected them, without refuge or protection, one will descend to the Avīci hell.
Therefore, should you aspire to attain 
The supreme primordial wisdom of the Buddhas,
Place your faith in this Mother of the Victorious Ones;
Like a merchant who journeys to the Isle of Jewels,
It would be utterly foolish to return empty-handed.


The purity of form should be understood as the purity of fruit;
The purity of form and fruit culminate in the purity of omniscience.
The purity of omniscience, the purity of fruit, and the purity of form
Are like the space element—indivisible and inseparable.
# The Knowledge of All Bases

This is the third section explaining the knowledge of all bases.

Through the Perfection of Wisdom, the heroes who skillfully practice between samsara and nirvana
Have completely transcended the three elements, yet avoid the extreme of peace, not resting in one-sided liberation;
Though they have eliminated afflictions, they retain subtle conditions to manifest arising by their own power;
Though free from aging, sickness, and death, like birds soaring freely, they display these sufferings for beings trapped in samsara.
These sentient beings cling to the quagmire of name and form,
Wandering in saṃsāra's cycle that turns like the cosmic wheel of winds.
Recognizing deluded sentient beings as deer trapped in snares of their own making,
Those endowed with wisdom soar like birds in the boundless sky.
A bodhisattva of wholly purified practice who does not grasp at form,
Nor engage with consciousness, perception, feeling, or volition as inherently existent,
Practicing thus in equanimity, abandons all attachments without exception;
Liberated from attachment, one engages in the wisdom of the Sugatas.


Thus, the wise and luminous bodhisattva practicing in this way
Having cut attachment's bonds, moves through beings with perfect freedom;
Like the sun shining brilliantly when released from Rahu's eclipse,
Like a blazing fire that consumes grass, tree, and forests completely.
When a bodhisattva perceives through the Perfection of Wisdom
That all phenomena are intrinsic nature pure and utterly pristine,
Neither the perceiver nor any phenomena are not apprehended—
This is the supreme practice of the Perfection of Wisdom.


# The Fourth Section: Teaching the Complete Realization of All Aspects

Indra, the lord of gods, asked the Victorious One:
"How does a bodhisattva practice the perfection of wisdom with diligent effort?"

Not engaging with aggregates and elements even the slightest particle,
Not making diligent effort toward aggregates—this is how a bodhisattva makes diligent effort.
Know that one who hears this Dharma teaching—
That all phenomena are like emanations and illusions—
And embraces it without doubt, training with repeated effort,
Is a sentient being who embarked on the Mahāyāna long ago
And has made excellent offerings to countless billions of Buddhas.
A person who has traveled many yojanas on a wilderness path,
Seeing the abundant forests at the boundary where herdsmen dwell,
Thinks, "These are signs that villages and cities are near,"
Finds relief and no longer fears the threat of bandits.
Thus, when one earnestly seeks the awakening of the Victorious Ones,
And comprehends this Perfection of Wisdom,
They find profound relief like a traveler catching breath, and all fear dissolves—
No longer will they fall to the earth of Arhats nor to the realm of Pratyekabuddhas.
When one journeys to behold the ocean's vastness,
If trees, forests, and mountains still appear, they know the path continues.
But when these signs no longer meet the eye, they think with perfect certainty:
"The great ocean is near at hand"—and in this, they harbor not a shadow of doubt.
Thus should one who has set forth toward supreme awakening be known:
One should hear and knowing this Perfection of Wisdom, mother of Victorious Ones.
Even without receiving a face-to-face prophecy from the Guide,
I will, before long, touch the buddha enlightenment.
In the auspicious spring, when trees shed their old leaves,
Before long, branches bloom with fresh leaves, fruits, and flowers;
Whoever attains this Perfection of Wisdom in their hands—both text and practice—
Before long, they will attain the awakening of the Guides who lead beings from suffering.
Just as a pregnant woman experiencing labor suffering
Is recognized to have reached her time of delivery;
So too a bodhisattva, having attained the seventh ground, hearing the wisdom of the Victorious Ones,
Develops joy and earnest aspiration, quickly touching awakening.
Practicing the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,
The yogin perceives neither increase nor decrease in form.
One who sees neither Dharma nor non-Dharma, nor conceptualizes the dharmadhātu itself,
And does not touch nirvana—such a one abides in wisdom.
One who practices here without conceptualizing the Buddha qualities,  
Who does not conceptualize powers, miraculous powers, their bases, nor peaceful awakening,  
Who acts non-conceptually through the sustaining power of blessings—  
This is the supreme practice of the Perfection of Wisdom.


Elder Subhūti asked the Buddha, the moon among speakers:
"What obstacles arise for those who have joy in qualities?"
The Teacher proclaimed: "Many obstacles will arise;
For now, I shall briefly enumerate just a few of them.\
When writing this Perfection of Wisdom of the Victorious Ones,
Various unstable confidences arise, fragmenting the mind in multiple ways;
Then, like lightning, they swiftly vanish before accomplishing sentient beings' purpose—
This complete falling away from practice is the karma of Māra.
When the Perfection of Wisdom is explained, some will harbor doubt, thinking:
"The Guide has not mentioned my self specifically in these teachings,
Nor declared my lineage, earth, or clan."
This is not mere decline but complete abandonment—Māra's karma,
Thus, in their ignorance, those under Māra's sway abandon the root—
The Perfection of Wisdom, mother of omniscience—and deludedly seek mere branches and leaves.
Like finding an elephant, then foolishly searching for its tracks—
So too are those who, having heard the Perfection of Wisdom, forsake the Mahāyāna path to pursue lesser vehicles.
Just as one who finds food with a hundred tastes,
Yet having obtained this supreme nourishment, foolishly seeks inferior fare;
So too does a bodhisattva who discovers these perfections,
Likewise pursue awakening through the limited path of an Arhat.
They will crave respect and pursue material gain,
With minds clinging to wrong views, cultivating closeness with households.
Abandoning the true Dharma, they engage in non-Dharma practices—
Forsaking the authentic path to wander on wrong paths—this is Māra's karma.
Those who at that time, with eager faith arise,
And journey forth to hear this supreme Dharma,
Will recognize the Dharma teacher engaged in improper acts,
And depart with heavy minds, their joy now turned to absence of happiness.
At that time, the karma of Māra will arise.
At that time, some will sow discord among many monks,
Thereby preventing this Perfection of Wisdom from being truly grasped.
Various obstacles, both inner and outer, will likewise emerge.
Those precious jewels that, once obtained, become priceless beyond measure,
Are exceedingly rare and constantly threatened by countless dangers.
Just so is the supreme Perfection of Wisdom of the Victorious Ones—
This precious Dharma treasure is equally rare and beset by many perils.
When sentient beings newly entering the vehicle, with limited wisdom,
Have not truly found this precious jewel of the Perfection of Wisdom,
Māra becomes eager to create obstacles in their way,
While Buddhas throughout the ten directions engage in completely grasping them.


When a Mother falls ill, her many children gather near,  
Their minds filled with distress, they tend to her with care.  
So too, across the ten directions in countless world-realms,  
The Buddhas watch over this supreme wisdom, their Mother sublime.
All World Protectors of the past, those who dwell throughout the ten directions,
And those who will arise in future times—all are born from this karma;
She is the Mother who gives birth to the Victorious Ones, Teachers of the world,
Who enables them to perceive the mental practices of all other sentient beings.
The suchness of the world and the suchness of Arhat,
The suchness of Pratyekabuddha and the suchness of Bodhisattva—
This suchness is singular, devoid of substance, not different in any way.
Through the Perfection of Wisdom, the Tathāgata knows this truth.
Whether the wise ones remain in the world or have passed into nirvana,
This nature of reality—the emptiness of all phenomena—abides unchanged.
Bodhisattvas come to realize this suchness,
And therefore, Buddhas are honored with the name "Tathāgata.\
This is the domain of the Guides with their ten powers,
Who support the joyful garden of the Perfection of Wisdom;
Though they completely liberate suffering sentient beings from the three lower realms,
They never form even a momentary perception of "sentient beings.\
Just as a lion, taking refuge in a mountain cave, roars fearlessly,
Naturally causing the small wild creatures to tremble in fear,
So the human lion, firmly established in the Perfection of Wisdom,
Naturally frightens many non-Buddhist philosophers while resounding the Dharma's profound truth throughout the world.
Just as the sun's rays abiding in the boundless expanse of sky
Dries this earth while revealing all forms without effort;
So too the Dharma King, supported by the Perfection of Wisdom,
Dries up the rivers of craving while effortlessly revealing the Dharma's profound nature.
Neither forms are seen, nor are feelings perceived,
Perceptions are unseen, and volitions unobserved.
Where consciousness, mind, and mind find no ground for appearance,
This, the Tathāgata taught, is truly seeing the Dharma.
"I see space," sentient beings commonly say,  
But examine closely: how is space truly seen?  
Just so, the Tathāgata taught, is how phenomena are perceived—  
This seeing cannot be explained through any other metaphor.


Whoever sees in this way—beyond conventional seeing—sees all phenomena;
Like a king remaining at ease while ministers govern all domains and territories,
All the Buddha's enlightened activities and the liberating qualities of the Śrāvakas—however many;
All these are performed by the Perfection of Wisdom, fulfilling the path of the three vehicles.
Just as a king does not travel to villages nor journey to realms,  
Yet from his own domain, he gathers all the tributes due to him;  
So too, the bodhisattva's nature of reality moves nowhere from its true nature,  
Yet attracts and gathers every quality of the Buddha's earth.


The one with unwavering faith in the Sugatas and bodhisattvas,  
Who both contemplates and actively engages with the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,  
Having completely transcended the two grounds of Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas,  
Will swiftly attain the invincible awakening of the Victorious Ones.
Just as when a vessel breaks apart in the ocean's depths,
One who fails to grasp a floating corpse, grass, or piece of tree
Will perish in the waters, never reaching shore;
Yet whoever does grasp these will cross to the far shore beyond.
Thus, those endowed with faith who have attained inspiration,
If they do not follow the Mother Perfection of Wisdom, cannot attain enlightenment.
When the qualities of skillful means are thoroughly infused with wisdom,
One swiftly touches the supremely wondrous awakening of the Sugata.
Just as one who carries water in an unbaked clay vessel
Will quickly see it perish due to its fragility,
So a bodhisattva with faith alone, lacking wisdom's understanding of emptiness,
Falls from the path.

But water borne in a well-fired pot along the path
Faces no danger of perishing or spilling;
Thus with method and wisdom united, beyond the lesser vehicles,
One safely reaches supreme enlightenment's abode of happiness.
Similarly, though a bodhisattva may abound in faith,
Without wisdom that realizes emptiness and selflessness, they swiftly fall into lower paths.
When faith is thoroughly embraced by wisdom's penetrating insight,
They transcend the two grounds to attain supreme enlightenment.
Just as an ill-prepared vessel perishes in the ocean's depths,
Sinking with its merchants and all their wealth;
So too that same vessel, when skillfully repaired with wisdom's craft,
Crosses to enlightenment's shore intact, its precious cargo safe.
Though a bodhisattva may be thoroughly imbued with faith,  
Without wisdom, they will swiftly fall away from awakening.  
But if that same one possesses the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,  
Unharmed and unblemished, they will touch the Victorious Ones' awakening.
A man of one hundred and twenty years, aged and tree suffering,  
Though he may arise from, cannot sentient beings onward by his self alone.  
But when supported by people on both his left and right,  
He travels with happiness, free from any fear of falling.
Just as a bodhisattva with feeble wisdom
Will falter on the path despite sincere commitment—
Like an elder who cannot stand alone—
When supported by the union of skillful means and wisdom,
This same practitioner will not decline
But will attain the supreme awakening of the Tathāgata.


Those bodhisattvas in the stage of initial karma,  
Who have entered the path to supreme enlightenment with noble resolve,  
These excellent disciples, filled with reverence for their teachers,  
Should constantly rely upon wise ones.
Why is that so? Because from reliance on virtuous spiritual friends arise the qualities of the wise.
They teach the Perfection of Wisdom in proper sequence.
"All the Buddha phenomena depend on virtuous spiritual friends,"
Thus spoke the Victorious One, who possesses the supreme of all qualities.
Generosity and ethical discipline, patience, and likewise diligent effort,
Meditative absorption and wisdom—dedicate these fully to awakening.
Do not conceptualize awakening as composed of aggregates or grasping it as inherently supreme;
Thus should those newly entering the Mahāyāna path be instructed.
Thus practicing, these moon among speakers—oceans of excellent qualities—
Become the refuge, supporting allies, and abide for sentient beings throughout the world.
They are the support toward liberation, the discerning wisdom, the island amid saṃsāra's floods, the guides who fulfill all aspirations and desires for purpose;
They illuminate the nature of reality, shine as lamps dispelling ignorance's darkness, teach the sublime Dharma with perfect skill, remaining unshakable before all adversaries.
Those of great renown don armor most difficult to bear,
Yet their armor is not of aggregates, elements, or sense fields.
Free from perceptions of the three vehicles, they grasp at nothing;
Irreversible, unwavering, they possess the phenomena of unshakability.
Those who possess these phenomena remain free from conceptual elaboration,  
Having dispelled all doubt, doubt, and mind hesitation, they grasp the true purpose.  
Upon hearing the Perfection of Wisdom, they never lose heart,  
Not relying on others in understanding, they should be known as irreversible on the path.
This Dharma of the Guides is profound, difficult to see—  
No one has realized it, nor is there anything to attain.  
Thus, having attained awakening, the Benefactor with compassion  
Thought, "Who among these multitudes of sentient beings will understand?" and remained undisturbed.
Sentient beings delight in abiding places and crave sensory objects,
Trapped in grasping, unwise and lost in darkness of delusion.
Yet the Dharma to be attained is without abode, beyond all grasping—
Thus arises conflict between the world that clings and this ungraspable truth.


The space element in the eastern direction and in the south,
Likewise in the western and northern regions, extends limitless beyond measure.
Above and below, throughout all ten directions however many there are,
It exists without differentiation, without any distinction whatsoever.
The suchness of what has passed is the suchness of what is yet to come;  
The suchness of the present moment is the suchness of the Arhat.  
The suchness of all phenomena is the suchness of the Victorious Ones';  
All these expressions of suchness remain utterly without distinction.
Should any bodhisattva wish to attain
The awakening of the Sugatas—free from all differentiated phenomena—
They must engage in the perfection of wisdom, the mother of all Guides;
For without this non-referential wisdom that realizes emptiness,
Though endowed with skillful means and great compassion,
The supreme awakening of the Lords of humanity remains unattainable.
If a bird of tremendous size, spanning one hundred and fifty yojana,
Were to find its wings withered away, bereft of strength and power,
And should it attempt to leap from the Realm of Thirty-Three
Down to our world of Jambudvīpa, it would surely meet with ruin.
Even if one cultivates these five perfections of the Victorious Ones  
For countless millions of eons and billions of eons,  
And constantly relies on boundless, vast aspirations in the world,  
Without skillful means and lacking wisdom, one still falls to the level of a Śrāvaka.
Whoever strives for liberation through the Buddha Vehicle,
Should view all sentient beings with equanimity as parents, with impartial mind;
With benevolence for their ultimate freedom and loving-kindness for their mind,
Let them actively guide others—being wholly sincere, harmless, and gentle in speech.


The Elder Subhūti thoroughly questioned the World Protector:
"Please reveal the signs of those who possess an ocean of qualities yet remain free from afflictions.
How do these mighty ones maintain their irreversible state on the path to enlightenment?
I ask you, O Victorious One, to prophecy even a fraction of the qualities by which we may recognize them.\
Free from the perception of difference, they speak words endowed with reasoning,
They do not rely on other ascetics and brahmins for support,
The wise ones at all times have permanently avoided the three lower realms,
And they make diligent effort on the ten paths of virtuous karma.
These irreversible bodhisattvas on the path of preparation teach the Dharma with absolute selflessness,
Single-mindedly devoted to the profound Dharma, their gentle speech flowing from genuine realization.
In walking, moving, lying down, and sitting, their unbroken mindfulness overcomes all obscurations,
Gazing just a yoke's length ahead as they proceed with minds perfectly clear, free from confusion.
Purified, wearing clean robes, their body, speech, and mind secluded and pure,
Not seeking worldly gain; like mighty bulls they lead, constantly yearning for Dharma alone,
Having transcended Māra's domain, not relying on others,
They meditate on the four meditative absorptions, yet never not abiding attached to their blissful states.
They neither seek fame nor harbor minds ensnared by anger;
Though living as householders, they remain forever unattached to worldly things.
For their livelihood, they never pursue wealth through harmful means;
They practice neither violent spells nor mantras to seduce women.
These irreversible bodhisattvas, abandoning wrong livelihood, do not prophesy whether those engaged in sensual karma will bear sons or daughters;
Devoted to the Perfection of Wisdom in profound inner solitude, they remain free from quarrels and disputes, with hearts of steadfast loving-kindness;
Aspiring to perfect omniscience, their minds unwavering as Mount Meru despite Māra's challenges, they continuously engage in Dharma practices, willing to sacrifice even their lives for its sake.
Through their aspirations, they choose not to be reborn in borderlands where barbarians dwell,
Unshakable as Mount Meru, they remain free from doubt about their realization,
Willingly sacrificing life for Dharma's sake, they diligently apply diligent effort in yogic practice—
These should be recognized as definitive signs of irreversible bodhisattvas.


Form, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness—
Profound in nature, signlessness, and completely at profound peace;
Like one who seeks to fathom the ocean's depths with an arrow,
When examined with wisdom, no foundation of the aggregates can be found.
The bodhisattva who, transcending extremes, has become profound in wisdom,
Realizes this Dharma of the ultimate vehicle free from attachment—
Where aggregates, elements, and sense fields have no inherent existence—
What could surpass the perfect merit that frees one from countless eons of saṃsāra?
Just as a person engrossed in attachment practices,
Who arranges to meet a woman but fails to encounter her—
For however many thoughts as arise in his mind throughout that single day,
For that many kalpas will a bodhisattva contemplating emptiness attain merit.
Though a bodhisattva might offer gifts to Arhats and Pratyekabuddhas for thousands of millions of kalpas,
And likewise maintain impeccable ethical discipline throughout this time,
One who teaches the phenomena imbued with the supreme Perfection of Wisdom
Creates merit that surpasses all generosity and ethical discipline, not even comparable to their hundredth part.
A bodhisattva who, cultivating supreme wisdom,
Arise from that meditation to teach the Dharma untainted by defilement,
And dedicates this virtue for sentient beings' purpose as a cause for awakening—
No virtue in all three worlds can equal this sublime practice.
That merit too is to be known as a heap, likewise empty,
Hollow, illusory, and without essence.
If one practices in this way the wisdom of the Sugatas,
While practicing, one completely grasps immeasurable merit.
Knowing that all phenomena taught, practiced, and illuminated by the Buddha
Are merely verbal expressions and nothing more,
Even if one were to speak of them for millions of eons upon billions of eons,
The dharmadhātu is inexhaustible and neither increases.
The perfections taught by the Victorious Ones—
Even these phenomena are proclaimed as merely nominal.
The bodhisattva who dedicates merit without conceit
Will be unwavering and will realize the supreme enlightenment of the Buddhas.


When the sesame oil wick first meets the flame,
It is not consumed, yet without this contact it cannot burn at all.
The final touch of flame alone cannot consume the wick completely,
And without this final flame, the wick cannot be fully consumed.
The initial mind does not directly touch supreme enlightenment,
Yet without this beginning, supreme enlightenment cannot possibly be touched.
The final mind does not attain peaceful awakening,
Yet without this culmination, awakening cannot possibly be attained.
From a seed emerge the sprout, flower, and fruit;  
Though the seed itself has ceased, it's not that the tree doesn't exist.  
Likewise, the initial mind is the cause of awakening;  
Though that mind has ceased, it's not that awakening doesn't exist.

As water droplets fill a vessel from first to last,
Gradually accumulating, little by little, until completely full;
So too the initial mind becomes the cause of supreme enlightenment,
And step by step, one perfects all virtuous qualities to become a Buddha.
Practicing the phenomena of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness,
Neither touching nirvana nor dwelling in the realm of conceptual signs—
Like a wise boatman who navigates back and forth across the waters,
Not abiding at either shore nor abiding in the ocean's midst.
Thus practicing, the bodhisattva harbors no thought:
"I have been prophesied by the One with ten powers and will attain awakening."
Nor do they fear awakening, thinking "nothing exists here at all."
Practicing in this way is to practice the wisdom of the Sugatas.
Witnessing worlds with wilderness paths, famine, and illness spreading,
Fearless, they don armor of aspiration to purify dual buddha-fields;
Practicing with diligent effort endlessly, thoroughly understands methods with emptiness wisdom,
Their minds, moved by compassion, generate not even the slightest particle of weariness.


The bodhisattva practices the wisdom of the Victorious Ones,
Realizing these aggregates as primordially empty and unborn from the beginning.
When not in meditative equipoise, they extend compassion to all realms of sentient beings,
And in those moments too, they never waver from the Buddha qualities.
Just as a person, a wise one endowed with every qualities,
Mighty and invincible, who makes diligent effort in mastering arts and rituals,
Who has reached perfection in archery and mastered many crafts that abide,
Who knows how to perform illusion and greatly desires the welfare of beings.
As a bodhisattva gathering father, mother, wife and children,
Then proceeding on wilderness paths beset with numerous foes,
One manifests many brave and heroic persons through skillful means,
Traveling with happiness yet returning home again—never abandoning samsara.
Similarly, at such time, the wise bodhisattva
Generates great compassion throughout all realms of sentient beings.
Having thoroughly transcended the four Māras and surpassed the two vehicles,
Abides in supreme meditative absorption, yet does not touch awakening.
Upon space rests the wind, and upon the wind rests the aggregates of water;
Upon water rests this great earth, and upon earth dwell all sentient beings.
This cosmic order manifests as the field where sentient beings' karma practice;
Contemplate this profound purpose: how space abides beyond all dependencies.
Just as the bodhisattva abiding in emptiness,
Displays manifold diverse activities throughout the beings,
Grounded in wisdom and aspirations toward sentient beings,
Neither touching nirvana nor dwelling in empty.
When the wise bodhisattva, whose luminous illuminates the darkness of ignorance,
Practices this supreme meditative absorption that realizes peaceful emptiness,
At this intermediate stage along the path, they remain free from conceptual signs;
Abiding in signlessness, they rest in the peace of samsaric turmoil and profound peace.
A bird flying through the sky leaves no trace, has no place to abide,  
Neither abiding in the air nor falling to the ground below.  
So too does the bodhisattva, practicing at the doors of liberation,  
Neither cling to the peace of nirvana nor engage in the realm of conceptual signs.
Just as a skilled trained person launches an arrow into the heavens,
Then mindfully sends forth others in succession, connecting them in an unbroken chain,
Preventing the first from falling to earth through sustained intention,
So long as desired; when the purpose is fulfilled, the arrows will descend.
Thus practicing the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,  
Engaging with wisdom, skillful means, power, and miraculous powers,  
As long as their roots of virtue remain incomplete,  
They will not attain that supreme emptiness.
Just as a monk endowed with supreme miraculous powers,
Dwelling in the sky, displays manifold wonders simultaneously,
Demonstrating beings, moving about, reclining, and sitting—
All without weariness or fatigue;
Just so, the wise bodhisattva abides in empty,
Having reached the far shore of primordial wisdom and miraculous powers, without abiding anywhere,
Displaying limitless varieties of activities for sentient beings,
Neither experiencing weariness nor physical fatigue through millions of eons.
Just as one might stand at the edge of a great earth,  
Holding two umbrellas firmly with both hands, and leap  
Into the open space, casting their body over the vast abyss—  
Yet not falling, but traveling onward as long as they remain aloft.
Thus, the wise bodhisattva abiding in compassion,
Fully grasping the dual umbrellas of skillful means and wisdom,
Contemplates all phenomena as empty, signlessness, and wishlessness,
Yet perceives the Dharma without touching nirvana.
Just as one seeking precious jewels voyages to the Isle of Jewels,
And having found these treasures, returns home once more;
There, not only does the merchant captain himself live with happiness,
But he ensures his circle of relatives and friends are not left with minds in distress.
Thus the bodhisattva, having journeyed to the precious jewel island of empty,
And attained the powers of meditative absorption and spiritual faculties,
Does not merely delight in touching nirvana without fully abiding therein,
Yet remains undistressed by the suffering of sentient beings while working tirelessly for their welfare.
Just as a merchant seeking purpose, to learn the route's geography,
Travels through cities, towns, and villages that lie between,
Yet not abiding neither there nor on the Isle of Jewels,
Nor keeps knowing not abiding at home—thus becoming wise in the path.
Similarly, the bodhisattva clearly understands
All aspects of the wisdom and liberation of Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas.
Yet they not abide neither in those paths nor in Buddha primordial wisdom itself;
They do not abide on the unconditioned—thus they truly know the method of the path.
When one connects with all beings through loving-kindness,
And practices the meditative absorption of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness—
Is it possible they will attain nirvana?
Or can they be designated as remaining in the conditioned phenomena? Without abode.
Just as an emanated human form is visible to perception
And can be designated by name despite lacking inherent existence,
So too a bodhisattva engaging in the doors of liberation—
Can likewise be designated by name in conventional terms while transcending both samsara and nirvana.
When questioned thoroughly about practice and faculties,
If a bodhisattva fails to illuminate the profound phenomena,
Cannot explain emptiness, signlessness, and the qualities of irreversible—
Know that this one has not received the Buddha's prophecy.
# The Fifth Section: Teaching the Complete Realization of the Summit

**Neither the Arhat earth nor the primordial wisdom of conditioned Buddhas do they desire,**
**Even in dreams, they never touch the three elements of existence.**
**Beholding the Buddhas and teaching the Dharma to beings in their dreams—**
**This should be understood as the prophecy of irreversible.**
In dreams, the bodhisattva sees sentient beings abide in the three lower realms,
And in that very moment makes aspirations to cut off the stream of these realms.
By the blessing of truth's power, raging fire aggregates are pacified—
This should be knowing as a prophecy of irreversible.
In the human world, where many spirits possess beings and numerous illnesses afflict them,
The power and blessing of truth, spoken with compassionate benefit, pacifies these afflictions.
The bodhisattva who does this harbors neither conceit about this ability nor pride—
This should be recognized as the sign of one who has received the prophecy of irreversible.


If one develops conceit, thinking, "I have received a prophecy,"
Due to various authentic-seeming blessings and accomplishments,
Or if a bodhisattva becomes proud of prophecies given by others—
Know that one who abides in such conceit is of limited wisdom.
Approaching through the basis of names, Māra comes near
And speaks thus: "These are your name and your parents' names,
And the names of your ancestors up to seven generations in your lineage.
And when you become a Buddha, this shall be your name.\
"What manner of disciplined practitioner with ascetic virtues will appear in yogic practice?"
"Even in your previous lives, your qualities were just this excellent"—thus speaks the deceiver.

The bodhisattva who, upon hearing such words, becomes filled with conceit
Should be recognized as one whose pride is fully aroused by Māra, with limited wisdom.
While dwelling in secluded villages, abandoned cities, mountain caves,
Making remote hermitages, places of solitude, and forest retreats their constant abode—
The bodhisattva who praises self while disparaging others
Should be recognized as one roused by Māra, of limited wisdom.
While abiding continually in villages, realms, and towns,
Apart from working to ripen sentient beings and striving for awakening with diligent effort,
They generate no desires for Arhat, Pratyekabuddha, or worldly pleasures—
This is what the spiritual heirs of the Sugata proclaim as true solitude.
Though one may dwell for millions of years in mountain caverns spanning five hundred yojanas,
Infested with venomous serpents throughout this vast expanse,
A bodhisattva who fails to understand the nature of true solitude
Remains in a contaminated state, filled with excessive pride.
When one disparages a bodhisattva who strives for sentient beings' purpose  
And has attained meditative absorptions, powers, faculties,  
liberations, and meditative absorptions, thinking:  
"This is not the practice of wilderness seclusion,"  
The Victorious One has declared such a person  
Abides within the realm of Māra.
Whether dwelling in a village or in wilderness retreat,
One who is free from the mind of the two vehicles and firmly resolved toward supreme enlightenment—
This is the true solitude for those engaged in the welfare of beings;
The bodhisattva who judges others' practice diminishes their own self.


Therefore, those who seek supreme awakening
Must, as wise ones skilled in the path, with powerful resolve conquer all pride,
Just as patients rely on physicians to cure their afflictions of illness—
So too, without lapse of attention, rely on virtuous spiritual friends.
Buddhas and bodhisattvas who have entered the supreme awakening,
Together with the perfections, are to be relied upon as virtuous spiritual friends.
These enlightened guides teach the very earth of practice to be accomplished;
Through these two causes, one quickly realizes the Buddha enlightenment.
The Victorious Ones of past, present, and future dwelling throughout the ten directions
All follow this path of perfection alone—no other can suffice.
For those who have set forth on the journey to supreme enlightenment,
This perfection serves as their illumination, their guiding lamp, their radiance that dispels ignorance,
And their supreme teacher showing the path beyond all obscurations.
Just as the Perfection of Wisdom is empty of defining characteristics,  
One who understands that all phenomena share this same nature,  
And thoroughly understands that phenomena are empty and without conceptual signs—  
Such practice is the practice of wisdom of the Sugatas.
Sentient beings, consumed by hunger, crave the nourishment of sensory delights;  
Those with minds attached to saṃsāra revolve endlessly in its grasp.  
Yet both self and phenomena belonging to self are unreal and utterly empty—  
Like ordinary beings casting knots into the void, beings bind themselves through their own delusion.
Just as one who suspects they've consumed poison may faint,
Even though no poison has actually entered their body,
So too do ordinary beings affirm and grasp at "self" and "mine,"
And through this false perception, are bound to the cycle of birth and impermanence in the buddha-field.
As one grasps, so affliction arises;
Freedom from not apprehended self and "mine" is taught as purification.
In ultimate reality, nothing ever becomes afflicted or purified—
This Perfection of Wisdom the bodhisattva realizes.
If every sentient beings throughout Jambudvīpa, however many there are without exception,  
Were to generate bodhicitta for supreme enlightenment,  
And practice generosity for many thousands of millions of years,  
Then dedicate all this as a cause for awakening for the purpose of sentient beings—
Whoever strives with diligent effort in the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,
Even if they practice and teach it for just a single sun,
The merit from vast aggregates of generosity cannot match even a fraction of theirs.
Therefore, engage in wisdom continuously, without a moment's laziness.
When practicing the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,
The yogin generates great compassion, yet has no perception of sentient beings as inherently existent.
At that moment, this wise one becomes a supreme field of generosity for all sentient beings—
One who partakes of the realm's offerings in a way that is perpetually purposeful, transforming ordinary consumption into a vehicle for liberation.
The bodhisattva who yearns to free beings bound as our kin through countless lives—
Gods, humans, and those suffering in the three lower realms of saṃsāra—
And wishes to reveal the vast path to the far shore for all realms of sentient beings,
Must diligently apply diligent effort to the Perfection of Wisdom, day and night.
Like one who finds a precious jewel they've never seen before,
And feels such joy upon this treasure in their hands,
Yet through carelessness lets it slip away soon after finding it,
Then suffers endlessly, longing for that precious jewel they lost.
Just as those who've entered the supreme enlightenment path—rare and precious as a precious jewel—  
Should never abandon their yogic practice with the Perfection of Wisdom.  
Like one who, finding a priceless treasure, seizes it and wraps it with diligent effort lest it be lost,  
They swiftly journey toward peace, attaining the perfect nirvāṇa beyond all suffering.


When the sun rises with its radiant network of rays, free from clouds,
It dispels all dense darkness completely;
It outshines all fireflies, living beings and beings,
Outshines the multitude of stars and even the moon's light.
Thus do bodhisattvas who practice the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,
Engaging in emptiness and signlessness with masterful skill,
Vanquish the dense thicket of false views
And outshines all beings, Arhat, Pratyekabuddha, and countless bodhicitta.
Like a prince who shares giving freely and aspires to meaningful purpose,  
Who becomes foremost among all and worthy of everyone's approach,  
Even now, while still training, he brings joy to countless sentient beings;  
How much more when he ascends the throne, crowned with skillful means and abiding in royal authority?
In this way, the wise bodhisattva, skilled in practice of wisdom,
Bestows the gift of generosity, becoming beloved to gods and humans alike.
Even now they strive with diligent effort for the happiness of countless sentient beings—
How much more will they accomplish when abiding as the Dharma King!


At that moment, Māra becomes pierced with thorns of anguish,
Overcome by sorrow, exhausted with suffering, his mind disturbed and strength diminished.
"How might this bodhisattva's resolve be weakened?" he thinks with desperation,
And so he sets the directions ablaze and hurls meteors to inspire terror.
When wise ones cultivate powerful resolve,
And day and night contemplate the supreme purpose of Perfection of Wisdom,
Their body, mind, and speech soar freely like birds through the boundless sky—
How could the forces of darkness ever find an opportunity against them?
When bodhisattvas engage in physical fights and verbal disputes,
Harboring mutually antagonistic, angry minds toward one another,
Māra becomes overjoyed and physically exultant,
Thinking: "These two will become distant from the Victorious Ones' primordial wisdom.\
These two grow distant from each other, becoming like flesh-eating demons;
Both undermine the sacred vows they once made.
How can awakening exist for those filled with hatred and devoid of patience?
At such times, Māra and his legions rejoice with joy.
If a bodhisattva who has not yet attained a prophecy
Becomes angry and initiates a dispute with one who has,
For however many moments their mind harbors such flawed thoughts,
They must begin their journey anew, donning the armor for that many kalpas.
Through the perfection of patience, Buddhas touch awakening.
When unwholesome thoughts arise, one generates mindfulness, thinking, "This mind is not good."
One confesses and firmly vows restraint hereafter, even at life's cost,
Not delighting in wrongdoing—thus one trains in the Buddha's Dharma, not Māra's.


One who trains without grasping at any notion of training,
Who neither trainee nor phenomena to be trained in are apprehended,
Who does not have non-conceptualization of the duality of training and non-training—
Such a person truly trains in the Buddha qualities.
The bodhisattva who understands this training as illusory
Will never falter in ethical discipline nor drift into moral corruption.
They train in this to please the Buddhas, seeking their qualities,
Masterfully dwelling in supreme wisdom—beyond all reference point.
When the wise ones illuminators train in wisdom,
Not even a single non-virtue thought arises in their minds.
Just as when the sun traverses the sky with overpowering rays,
Darkness cannot not abide in the space before its radiance.
For those who have trained in the Perfection of Wisdom,
All other perfections are gathered within it.
Just as the sixty-two wrong views are contained within the view of the transitory collection,
So too, it is taught, are all these perfections encompassed within this one.
Just as when the life faculty ceases, all other faculties,
However many there may be, will likewise come to an end;
So too, for those supreme wise ones who practice wisdom,
All other perfections are taught to be contained within this one.
Wise bodhicitta train in every qualities
That Śrāvakas possess, and likewise
In all the qualities of Pratyekabuddhas.
Yet they neither abide in these states nor generate desire for them—
They train in them simply thinking, "These are training I must master, self.\


When one wholeheartedly rejoices in the bodhicitta
Of those who have irreversibly entered the path to supreme enlightenment,
The trichiliocosm Mount Merus could be weighed and measured on a scale,
But the virtue of such rejoicing remains immeasurable.
I rejoice in the aggregates of merit accumulated by all sentient beings
Who seek virtue and aspire to benefit others.
May they, having attained the qualities of the Victorious Ones,
Bestow the Dharma upon the world for the complete elimination of suffering.
The bodhisattva who, with non-conceptual awareness,
Deeply comprehends all phenomena as empty, signless, and free from conceptual elaboration,
Does not seek awakening through a dualistic framework of wisdom,
This yogin truly engages in the supreme Perfection of Wisdom with diligent effort.
Between the space element and space itself, there exists no contradiction;  
Neither can be said to exist [as opposing entities], nor can anyone attain them.  
Just so, the bodhisattva skilled in the practice of wisdom  
Is like space, moving through the world in perfect peace.
Like an illusion-created person among crowds,
Who never thinks, "I must delight these people,"
Yet still performs such acts;
And though observers witness its display of wondrous miraculous powers,
It possesses neither body, mind, nor even name.
Thus, one who practices wisdom never thinks,  
"Having realized awakening, I shall liberate all sentient beings."  
Yet displays various arisings and engages in manifold activities,  
And though appearing like an illusion, moves beyond all non-conceptual practice.
Just as a Buddha's emanation performs all Buddha activities,
Yet never develops the slightest trace of pride in doing so,
Likewise, bodhisattvas skilled in practice of wisdom
Display all their activities as emanations, like illusions.
Just as a wise woodworker creates figures of men and women,
Which then perform all manner of actions without conscious thought,
So too do bodhisattvas, skilled in practice of wisdom,
Accomplish all activities through non-conceptual primordial wisdom.


Thus to those skilled in practice, vast assemblies of gods
Approach with joined palms, bowed heads, and offer full prostrations in reverence.
Even all the Buddhas throughout the world-realms of the ten directions
Continually proclaim garlands of praise, honoring these noble, heroic beings.
If all sentient beings dwelling in buddha-fields as numerous as the sands of the Ganges  
Were to harbor malicious thoughts and transform themselves into Māras,  
And if from each hair on their bodies they emanated an equal multitude of emanations—  
Even then, all these forces combined could not create the slightest obstacle for the wise one.
Through four causes, the wise bodhisattva, endowed with power,
Cannot be overcome by the four Māras, unmovable from their path.
Abiding in emptiness, yet never abandoning sentient beings,
Fulfilling their proclaimed vows, blessed by the Sugatas' grace.
When this Perfection of Wisdom, Mother of the Tathāgatas across all three times,
Is being explained, if a bodhisattva develops deep faith in it,
And wholeheartedly diligently strives to put it into practice,
Know that they have truly entered the state of omniscience.
Neither dwelling in the dharmadhātu nor abiding in suchness,
One remains like clouds in the open sky—present without abiding.
As a vidyāmantra holder who, without abode, causes through space yet seeks to abide,
Through the power of mantras, blesses buddha-fields to bloom with flowers out of season.
Thus practicing, the wise and luminous bodhisattva
Neither perceives the path that leads to emptiness, nor grasps at the Buddha qualities and fearlessnesses;
Neither conceives of teacher explaining, seeker desiring, nor observer contemplating Dharma—
This is the abiding of those who seek peace, delighting in the qualities of non-abiding nirvana.
Except for the liberation of Tathāgatas and Arhats,
This abiding transcends
All the peaceful meditative absorptions
Of Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas—
Those peace states endowed with bliss and profound peace.
Among however many such meditative abodes,
This abiding stands supreme and unsurpassed,
Balancing emptiness wisdom with compassion,
Benefiting self and others simultaneously.
Though birds dwell in the vast sky, they never fall;
Though fish live in water's depths, they remain untroubled and alive.
Likewise, bodhisattvas, through their powers of meditative absorption,
Having reached the far shore, abide in empty, yet do not pass into sorrow.
Whoever aspires to attain the supreme qualities of all sentient beings,
And longs to touch the supremely wondrous, extraordinary primordial wisdom of the Buddha,
And wishes to bestow the excellent, supreme, and supreme generosity of Dharma—
Should rely upon this supreme abide of those Benefactors.


When the Buddha, our Guide, explains this training in full,
Of all the however many trainings, this one stands supreme and unsurpassed.
The wise one who aspires to master every aspect of the far shore
Should train in this Perfection of Wisdom—the Buddha's ultimate teaching.
This is the supreme treasure of Dharma, the supreme repository,  
The source of Buddha lineage, a treasury of happiness and well-being for sentient beings.  
The World Protectors of the past and future, throughout the ten directions—  
All arise from this, yet the dharmadhātu remains inexhaustible.
All trees, fruits, flowers, and forests that however many exist—  
Each one emerges and springs forth from the earth.  
Yet the earth is inexhaustible and neither increases,  
Neither diminishes nor experiences without weariness, remaining non-conceptual.
All Buddhas, their spiritual heirs, Śrāvakas, Pratyekabuddhas, and gods,
Along with all happiness and phenomena of every sentient being, however many,
All these arise from the supreme Perfection of Wisdom,
Yet wisdom itself is neither exhausted nor increases.
However many sentient beings exist—inferior, middling, or superior—
The Sugata taught that all arise from the root ignorance that misconceives self.
When conditions converge, the suffering cycle and its twelve links manifest,
This cycle of delusion neither spontaneously diminishes nor increases in beings.
All approaches of primordial wisdom, entrances to the path, skillful means, and roots—
However many there are—arise from the supreme Perfection of Wisdom.
When conditions gather, the wheel of karma fully manifests,
Yet the Perfection of Wisdom, in its ultimate nature, neither diminishes nor increases.
The bodhisattva who realizes dependent origination
As unborn and inexhaustible through wisdom,
Like the sun dispersing darkness with rays when free from clouds,
Conquers the thick veil of twofold ignorance and attains self-arisen knowing inseparable from the dharmadhātu.


The mighty ones abide in the four meditative absorptions,
Yet they neither depend on nor dwell attached to these states.
Nevertheless, these four meditative absorptions with all their factors
Become the support for attaining supreme awakening.
Abiding in the meditative absorptions, the bodhisattva who has attained supreme wisdom
Also experiences the four supreme formless meditative absorptions without attachment.
These meditative absorptions directly contribute to the highest, supreme awakening;
The bodhisattva trains not to exhaust defilements but to benefit beings through transformative powers.
How wondrous, how marvelous this treasury of transcendent qualities!
They abide in meditative absorption and samādhi, remaining in signlessness.
If their bodies dissolve while abiding in these sublime states,
They take birth in the desire element according to will, like lotuses untainted by mud.
Just as someone from Jambudvīpa who had never before visited the realm of the gods,
Later journeys to the supreme city of the celestial beings,
And having witnessed those divine places fully occupied by gods,
If they were to return here, they would remain unattached.
Just so, these bodhisattvas, bearers of supreme qualities,
Having dwelled in meditation and meditative absorption as diligent yogic practice,
Return to abide in the desire element yet remain untouched by attachment—
Like lotuses in water, not abiding in the ways of ordinary beings.
These great self solely dedicate themselves
To maturing sentient beings, purifying buddha-fields, and perfecting the perfections.
Knowing the qualities of awakening and perfections would decline there,
They do not seek arising in the formless elements.
Just as a bodhisattva discovers profound meditative precious jewels,
Yet wisely refrains from attachment, knowing their conventional nature,
And later, with compassion, fully masters these attainments,
To return home and remain unattached for others' benefit;
In the same way, wise bodhisattvas, having attained  
The four peaceful meditative absorptions and meditative absorptions that bestow joy and happiness,  
Willingly relinquish the endowed with bliss meditative absorptions they've attained,  
And out of compassion for beings, return once more to the desire element.
If a bodhisattva abiding in meditative absorption
Develops aspirations for the Arhat or Pratyekabuddha vehicle,
They are not in meditative equipoise but agitated and distracted of mind—
Like a passenger on a shattered vessel, fallen from the qualities of Buddha.
Even though one may engage with form and sound,
With fragrance, taste, and touch—the five sense pleasures,
If one delights in bodhicitta, transcending the paths of Arhats and Pratyekabuddhas,
Know that this hero remains always in meditative equipoise.
For the sake of other sentient beings and persons, pure-minded bodhisattvas
Practice with manifest diligent effort in the perfection of diligent effort.
Just as a water-carrier maidservant, without autonomy, remains subject to her master's control,
So these courageous ones, who overcome self-cherishing, place themselves entirely under the will of all sentient beings.
Even when verbally abused with harsh speech or continuously beaten,
A servant woman offers no words of defiance to her master.
Overwhelmed by fear, her mind terrified and subdued,
She thinks, "He might kill me for this self very reason.\
Likewise, those who tread the supreme awakening seeking awakening
Should abide among all sentient beings as humble servants, enduring contempt and abuse;
By this karma of equalizing self and others, they attain awakening and perfect all qualities—
Just as fire, born from grass and tree, both consumes its source and transcends it.
Having abandoned my own happiness, with a mind utterly free from expectation,
I make diligent effort ceaselessly day and night for the needs of all sentient beings.
Like a mother tenderly caring for her only child with spontaneous love,
I shall abide wholeheartedly, never yielding to weariness until all are free.


That bodhisattva who willingly remains in cycle for ages,
A devoted yogin striving for the purpose of sentient beings and purifying buddha-fields,
Who never harbors even the slightest particle of discouragement—
Such a one possesses the perfection of diligent effort and knows no laziness.
The unwise bodhisattva counts millions of eons,
Perceiving the path to awakening as lengthy and filled with suffering.
When practicing the authentic Dharma, they will suffer for a long time,
Thus declining in the perfection of diligent effort, becoming affected by laziness.
From the moment one first generates bodhicitta,
Until the attainment of unsurpassed awakening,
If one contemplates in mind as though it were merely a single day and night,
Know this as the diligent effort initiated by the wise one, illuminated by luminosity.
If someone were to say, "First shatter Mount Meru,
And only after that will you attain supreme enlightenment,"
Should a bodhisattva grow discouraged at these words and begin to calculate the effort,
At that moment, they have fallen into laziness.
When a bodhisattva thinks, "If this is all it takes, what difficulty could there be?"
And generates a bodhicitta that could reduce Mount Meru to ashes in a single moment,
Such a wise one bodhisattva, who has aroused unwavering diligent effort,
Will, before long, attain the supreme enlightenment of the Guide.
If one thinks, "Having fully matured sentient beings, I will accomplish their purpose,"  
And strives with body, speech, and mind in this way,  
One abides in the notion of self, which becomes laziness—  
And remains as distant from omniscience as heaven is from earth.
When one is free from perceptions of body, mind, and sentient beings,
When all dualistic perceptions have been reversed, and one dwells in non-dual practice—
This is the perfection of diligent effort, as taught by the Beneficent One,
For those who aspire to supreme, peaceful, and unchanging awakening.
When hearing harsh and hurtful words spoken by others,
The wise one bodhisattva rejoices, thinking, "This brings me happiness to self."
Who is speaking? Who is hearing? By what means, what is said, and why?
One who embodies the supreme perfection of patience is truly wise.
That bodhisattva who embodies the noble Dharma of patience—
Should one fill the trichiliocosm with precious jewels
And offer them to the world-knowing Buddhas, Arhats, and Pratyekabuddhas,
The aggregates of generosity could not equal even a hundredth part of merit from patience.
For one abiding in patience, the body becomes utterly pure,  
Adorned with the thirty-two marks of greatness and boundless power.  
They proclaim the supreme Dharma of emptiness to all sentient beings—  
This wise one who embodies patience becomes beloved throughout the sentient beings.
If one person were to take fragrant sandalwood powder
And with deep reverence apply it to the bodhisattva,
While another scattered burning coals upon his head—
Toward both, he should cultivate a mind of perfect equanimity.
When the wise bodhisattva cultivates patience in this way,
And dedicates that bodhicitta toward supreme enlightenment,
This hero, through patience toward all beings in the world,
Outshines the Arhats, Pratyekabuddhas, and however many multitudes in the realms of sentient beings.
When practicing patience, I should cultivate this thought:
"In the hells, animal realm, and Yama's world of hungry ghosts, 
Having endured countless suffering without autonomy due to the causes of sense pleasures,
Why should I not practice patience now for the sake of awakening?\
Whips, sticks, and weapons; slaughter, imprisonment, and beatings;
Decapitation, cutting off of ears, limbs, and nose—
"However many suffering exists in this world, I as self shall endure it all,"
Thus thinking, the bodhisattva abides in the perfection of patience.


Through ethical discipline, those seeking peace become Noble,  
Abiding in the realm of the ten powers, their ethical discipline remains unwavering.  
They engage in every aspect of moral restraint practice, however many,  
And dedicate all merit to awakening for the benefit of all sentient beings.
If one desires to attain the awakening of Arhats and Pratyekabuddhas,  
Their ethical discipline is broken, their wisdom deficient, their practice deteriorated.  
But if one dedicates merit toward supreme awakening—the ultimate peace—  
Even while engaged with sensual pleasures, one abides in the perfection of ethical discipline.
That Dharma which surely gives rise to awakening's qualities—  
This is the true purpose of ethical discipline for those endowed with virtuous qualities.  
That which causes even those who help others to completely fall from awakening—  
This the Guide has proclaimed as moral corruption.
Even if a bodhisattva practices the five sense pleasures,
Yet takes refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and the Noble Saṅgha,
