And maintains in their mind the aspiration: "I shall become a Buddha, attaining omniscience,"
The wise one should know that such a one abides in the perfection of ethical discipline.
Even if you practice the ten virtuous paths of karma
For millions of eons, yet aspire to become
An Arhat or Pratyekabuddha for yourself alone,
Your ethical discipline becomes flawed and degenerate—such abandonment of bodhicitta is far graver than even the most serious monastic downfalls.
Guarding ethical discipline and dedicating merit fully to supreme enlightenment,
Without taking conceit in this or praising self,
Having completely abandoned perceptions of "I" and perceptions of "sentient beings,"
The bodhisattva is said to abide in the perfection of ethical discipline.
If a bodhisattva who practices the path of the Victorious Ones
Perceives, "These sentient beings uphold ethical discipline, while those others are morally corrupt,"
Engaged in such diverse conceptualizations, they become extremely corrupt in ethical discipline—
Their ethical discipline is damaged, and completely pure ethical discipline is absent in them.
For one devoid of perceptions of self and sentient beings,
For one free from perception and attachment, how could non-moral restraint exist?
For one without conceit regarding moral restraint or its absence,
This is what the Guide has taught as perfect ethical discipline.
The purified sentient beings, grounded in ethical discipline,
Perceives all things pleasant and unpleasant with wisdom beyond duality.
Offering even head and limbs with unwavering courage born of selflessness,
Relinquishes all possessions through giving, remaining forever untainted by attachment's grasp.
Having realized the selflessness intrinsic nature of all phenomena as illusory,
One who can offer even their own flesh without a trace of hesitation in the mind—
What need is there to mention their giving away of external possessions?
For such a one, miserliness has no place to abide.
When the notion of self arises, grasping at "mine" follows;
How could those deluded by such ignorance develop a mind of giving?
The miserly will be reborn in the realm where hungry ghosts abide;
And even if they attain human arising, they will suffer in poverty.
When the bodhisattva recognizes the poverty of sentient beings,
They become devoted to giving, giving freely and without reserve.
To them, the four richly adorned continents are but like specks of spittle—
Having given all away, they find joy, unlike those who gain worldly realms.
The wise, luminous bodhisattva, perceiving
All sentient beings throughout the three realms of existence,
Gives with the profound aspiration: "May this generosity be given to all,"
And dedicates this merit to supreme enlightenment for the purpose of all sentient beings.
The wise one, having given generosity, do not abide to what they've given,  
Nor do they ever anticipate rewards or karmic fruits.  
Thus skilled in the art of giving, they relinquish everything;  
By letting go of little, they gain immeasurable returns.
If every sentient beings throughout the three realms of existence,
When all are counted and taken into account, were to make offerings
To the World-Knowers, Buddhas, Arhats, and Pratyekabuddhas
For countless eons, while pursuing only the lesser path of the Śrāvakas,
When the wise one bodhisattva skilled in means
Rejoices in these merit actions,
And dedicates toward supreme awakening for the purpose of sentient beings,
Through such complete dedication, they outshine all sentient beings.
Though there may exist a massive heap of blue gemstones,
A single precious jewel vaiḍūrya gem outshines them all.
Similarly, all beings' vast aggregates of generosity 
Are outshined by the bodhisattva who rejoices.
When a bodhisattva bestows generosity upon all beings,
Without conceptualizing self, gift, or recipient as inherently real,
The mighty ones roots of virtue flourish simultaneously,
Like the radiant moon growing brighter in a cloudless sky.


The Sixth Section: Teaching on Gradual Progress

Through generosity, the bodhisattva cuts off rebirth as hungry ghosts,
Severs both poverty and likewise all afflictions completely.
While practicing this path, they attain boundless, abundant enjoyments,
Through generosity, they fully ripen sentient beings oppressed by suffering.
Through moral discipline, one avoids the many forms of animal realm rebirth  
And constantly obtains leisure by transcending the eight unfavorable conditions.  
Through patience, one acquires a supreme and magnificent form,  
With a golden complexion that is beautiful and worthy of the sentient beings' gaze.
Through diligent effort, virtuous qualities never wane,
Boundless primordial wisdom and the Victorious Ones' treasury one attains.
Through meditative absorption, one renounces base sense pleasures,
And manifests knowing, higher perceptions, and profound meditative absorption states.
Through wisdom, having thoroughly comprehended the intrinsic nature of all phenomena,  
One completely transcends the three elements of existence without exception.  
The supreme leader of humanity, having turned the precious jewel wheel of Dharma,  
Teaches the Dharma to all beings to achieve the complete elimination of their suffering.
## The Seventh Section: Attaining Complete Awakening in a Single Moment

Having completely perfected these phenomena, the bodhisattva,

## The Eighth Section: The Dharma Body (Dharmakāya)

Thoroughly embraces both the purified buddha-fields and the purity of sentient beings.
Likewise, they thoroughly uphold the Buddha-lineage and the Dharma-lineage.
Similarly, they maintain the Sangha-lineage and completely embrace all phenomena.
The supreme physician in the world who heals illnesses,
Has taught this wisdom containing the path to awakening;
Named "The Path to Awakening that Gathers Precious Jewel Qualities,"
This path is taught so that all sentient beings may attain it.



Here concludes the Noble Perfection of Wisdom Compendium in verse.
